links.*: A Closed Letter to Andrea Charicoryides Surnamed Polygrapheus, Logothete of the Theme of Geodesia in the Empire, Bard of the Court of Camelot, Malleus Malitiarium, Inclinga Sum Sometimes Known as Charles Williams
A Fragment of an Epic: Before Jerusalem Richard Makes an End of Speech
Adventures in Unnatural History and Medieval Metres, being the Freaks of Fisiologus
Bilbo's Last Song (at the Grey Havens)
Chip the glasses and crack the plates!
Cold be hand and heart and bone,
Dark Are the Clouds about the North
Far over the misty mountains cold
Farewell We Call to Hearth and Hall!
From dark Dunharrow in the dim morning
Hey dol! merry dol! ring a dong dillo!
Hop along, my little friends, up the Withywindle!
I Sit beside the Fire and Think
In Western Lands beneath the Sun
Lemminkainen Goeth to the Fords of Oxen
Over Old Hills and Far Away
Over the land there lies a long shadow
Poems in The Lord of the Rings
Seek for the Sword that was broken
Sir Gawain and the Green Knight
Song of the Ent and Entwife
Song of the Mounds of Mundburg
Tha Eadigan Saelidan: The Happy Mariners
The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien
The Complaint of Mîm the Dwarf
The Homecoming of Beorhtnoth Beorhthelm's Son
The J.R.R. Tolkien Companion and Guide
The Last of the Old Gods
The Lay of Aotrou and Itroun
The Lay of the Children of Húrin
The Lay of the Fall of Gondolin
The Lion Is Loud and Proud
The Little House of Lost Play: Mar Vanwa Tyaliéva
The Man in the Moon Came Down Too Soon
The Man in the Moon Stayed Up Too Late
The Swallow, and the Traveller on the Plains
The wind was on the withered heath
The world was young, the mountains green,
Twenty years have flowed away down the long river
Under the mountain dark and tall
When winter first begins to bite
Where now the horse and the rider? Where is the horn that was blowing?
The Mermaid's Flute from 'The Lay of Earendel'
The Horns of the Host of Doriath
An Ode Inspired by Intimations of the Approach of Early Morning Tea
Ye laggard woodlands and ye slumbrous brakes
I stood upon an empty shore before the sun was born
A Rhyme Royal upon Easter Morning
Moonshine: Verses in a Medieval Measure
Lines Composed in a Village Inn on an Evening of Extraordinary Liquid Beauty
The Tale of Beewolf Son of Echgethew
Völsungakviða en nýja eða Sigurðarkviða en mesta
Guðrúnarkviða en nýja eða Dráp Niflunga
Hit was an olde mon fro Pimbilmere
When little Louis came to stay
Though all things fail & come to naught,
My heart is not in this land where I live:
'At last the time has come,' he said,

wikitext.*:
{{Poem infobox | title=The Battle of the Eastern Field | other names= | written=Before [[March]] of [[1911]] | revised=After [[March]] of [[1911]] | published=''[[King Edward's School Chronicle]]'',
''[[Mallorn 12]]'',
''[[Mallorn 13]]'',
''[[Mallorn 46]]'',
''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'' | subject=[[Wikipedia:Rugby|Rugby match]] }} '''''The Battle of the Eastern Field''''' is a poem written by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] sometime before [[March]] of [[1911]] about a rugby match when he was still at [[Wikipedia:King Edward's School|King Edward's School]] in Birmingham.{{CG|I}}, p. 23 (entry "''March 1911''") It is notably the first{{TS|10}}, Volume X, "In Memoriam: Maggie Burns" poem that Tolkien published.{{CG|2II}}, entry "''The Battle of the Eastern Field''") ==Preface and first stanza== [On Friday March 31st I came across this curious fragment in the waste paper basket, in the Prefects' room. Much of it was so blotted that I could not decipher it. I publish it with emendations of my own. G.A.B.] I Ho, rattles sound your warnote! Ho, trumpets loudly bray! The clans will strive and gory writhe Upon the field to-day. To-day the walls and blackboards Are hung with flaunting script, From Atlas on the staircase To Bogey’s darkling crypt. Each knight is robed in scarlet, Or clad in olive green; A gallant crest upon each breast Is proudly heaving seen. While flows our Yellow River, While stands the great Pavil, That Thursday in the Lenten Term Shall be a beanfest still.{{CP|6}} ==Background== [[File:The King Edward's School Chronicle Vol. 25 No. 186 1911.jpg|250px|thumb|The King Edward's School Chronicle]] It is unknown exactly when Tolkien wrote the poem or whether any earlier versions survive, but it is possible that he wrote it in the same year that the poem was published. In [[March]] of [[1911]], ''The Battle of the Eastern Field'' was first published as entry 186 in the 26th issue of the ''[[King Edward's School Chronicle]]'' on pages 22–26. The mock author's notes published with the poem were signed with the pseudonym '''G.A.B.''', possibly short for '''Gabriel''', Tolkien's schoolboy nickname. Sometime shortly after the poem was published, Tolkien made an annotated copy that he signed with his initials. In [[1978]], the poem was reprinted in ''[[Mallorn 12]]'' on pages 24-28.{{webcite|author=|articleurl=http://www.tolkienbooks.net/php/details.php?reference=11180|articlename=''[[Mallorn 12]]''. 1978|dated=|website=TB|accessed=19 September 2013}} In an article published in ''[[Mallorn 13]]'' in [[1979]], the poem was first identified by Jessica Yates as being a parody of '[[Wikipedia:Lays of Ancient Rome/The Battle of the Lake Regillus|The Battle of Lake Regillus]]' from [[wikipedia:Thomas Babington Macaulay, 1st Baron Macaulay|Thomas Babbington Macaulay]]'s 1842 ''[http://www.theotherpages.org/poems/rome.html The Lays of Ancient Rome]''.''[[Mallorn 13]]'', "''The Battle of the Eastern Field'': A Commentary" by Jessica Yates, p. 5 In the autumn of [[2008]], the poem was reprinted again in ''[[Mallorn 46]]'' on pages 20-22 with commentary by Maggie Burns. In [[2017]], the first four lines were reprinted in the second edition ''[[The J.R.R. Tolkien Companion and Guide]]''. In [[September]] of [[2024]], the poem was included as entry 6 in ''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'' along with Tolkien's annotated copy. {{references}} {{poems}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Battle of the Eastern Field, The}} [[Category:Poems by J.R.R. Tolkien]] [[fi:The Battle of the Eastern Field]]
